Zhengzhou University China. Mercuric chloride as main catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination poses a serious hazard to the environment due to its easily volatilizing and highly toxic characteristics. Mercuric-free catalysts, especially metal-free catalysts, are quite intriguing in the industrial production of acetylene hydrochlorination. In this work, nitrogen-doped biochar is prepared as green metal-free catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination with natural walnut shells as starting material, in which the condensation product of dicyandiamide or dicyandiamide-formaldehyde is applied as nitrogen source. The 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst exhibits superior catalytic activity with C2H2 conversion of 94.5% at 220°C and 45 h−1, which is attributed to the high content of quaternary nitrogen as active center. The introduction of formaldehyde effectively inhibits the carbon deposition in the catalytic reaction and improves the thermal stability of metal-free nitrogen-doped biochar catalyst. This work provides a significant insight into the design of environmentally friendly metal-free nitrogen-doped biochar catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Walnut shell Acetylene hydrochlorination Metal-free catalyst Quaternary nitrogen Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In China, vinylchloride monomer (VCM), as the raw material of polyvinylchloride (PVC), is mainly manufactured through the method of coal-based acetylene hydrochlorination due to the coal-rich and oil-poor situation [1]. Since VCM is industrialized in Germany, the best catalyst in the process of acetylene hydrochlorination is the activated carbon supported mercuric catalyst, which adopts the highly toxic and volatile mercuric chloride as active component. However, the discharged mercury in the air poses a serious risk to human health and environment [2]. In response, more than 140 countries signed the Minamata Convention in 2013 with the purpose to limit the exploration and release of mercury [3]. Therefore, the development of environmentally friendly low-cost mercury-free catalysts becomes a vital subject for the sustainable production of VCM. Precious metal catalysis for acetylene hydrochlorination gradually becomes the research focus along with the pioneering work of Shinoda and Hutchings based on the correlation of catalytic activity with the intrinsic character of metal chloride on activated carbon [4,5]. Carbon-supported gold/ruthenium-based catalysts are proven to be the most promising alternative catalysts. And, the deactivation problem caused by the reduction of high valence has been essentially resolved by different approaches, such as additional metals and/or promoters [6–10], ligand-containing soft donor atoms [11–16], ionic liquids [17–23] and functionalized carbon carriers [24–27]. Unfortunately, the expensive cost of noble metals inevitably restricts their industrial application. Meanwhile, non-precious metal catalysis for acetylene hydrochlorination has also been developed with the purpose to replace mercuric catalysts. Based on a lot of optimized experiments, copper/bismuth-based catalysts reveal the outstanding activity and thermal stability beyond gold and mercury catalysts [28–31]. The researches on non-precious metal catalysts is still ongoing in the laboratory up to now [32]. More interestingly, heteroatom-doped carbon materials as metal-free catalysts also reveal excellent catalytic performance for acetylene hydrochlorination in recent years through the modification of carrier surface and the regulation of electron affinity [33]. The introduction of heteroatoms into carbon materials is extensively studied in photolytic water [34]. In particular, the nearly close electronegativity and electron affinity of nitrogen atom to carbon atom, together with its coordination action of lone pair electrons, have enabled nitrogen-doped carbon materials to exhibit excellent photocatalytic property. In acetylene hydrochlorination, numerous metal-free catalysts have been successively reported, such as nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes [35], nitrogen-doped porous carbon [36,37], nitrogen-containing MOF/polymer-derived nitrogen-doped carbon materials (such as ZIF-8 [38–40], polyaniline [41], poly(o-phenylenediamine) [42]), and different nitrogen source-loading activated carbon [43,44]. These metal-free catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination are usually prepared by chemical vapor deposition, direct carbonization of nitrogen-containing precursors, or the impregnation of nitrogen source into porous carbon. In these catalysts, quaternary nitrogen, pyridinic nitrogen, pyrrolic nitrogen or carbon atoms adjacent to nitrogen atoms have proven to be the active centers for acetylene hydrochlorination. It is more noteworthy that biomass-derived carbon materials are applied to the fabrication of nitrogen-doped metal-free catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination due to their low cost and environmental friendliness. In this regard, flour/soybean-derived nitrogen-doped carbon materials have respectively achieved the acetylene conversion of ∼85% and ∼99% under optimal conditions [45,46]. In view of abundant nitrogen content of natural walnut shells together with porous morphological structure, biomass carbon materials derived from walnut shells are expected to have more excellent performance for acetylene hydrochlorination. In China, there are an abundant of walnut shells as biomass wastes every year owing to the demands of kernel through walnut processing. These walnut shells present a wrinkled surface and a pore-rich structure for a huge specific surface area, which favors the achievement of extraordinary adsorption and catalytic performance on the basis of their biomass carbon materials. Besides, the abundant nitrogen content of natural walnut shells presents a large number of active catalytic sites inside their biochar. Therefore, many researchers have focused on the effective use of walnut shells in the catalysis and absorption fields. For example, Jin and coworkers used the walnut shell biochar for the adsorption of Hg0. In this case, the specific chemical structure of biochar surface guarantees the stable presence of Hg0, while the large amount of adsorption sites facilitate the adsorption of Hg0 [47]. Li and coworkers prepared a series of biomass carbon starting from walnut shells, which load the copper catalysts for the wet oxidation performance of phenol. Wherein, the large specific surface area and micropore volume of biomass carbon ensure a high copper-loading amount [48]. Notably, the walnut shell biomass carbons are not yet applied for acetylene hydrochlorination in spite of excellent adsorption and catalytic characteristics. In this work, environmentally friendly natural walnut shells are applied as the feedstock of nitrogen-doped biomass carbon materials to make the full use of abundant nitrogen sources for more active catalytic sites and porous morphological structure for larger specific surface area. Simultaneously, dicyandiamide-formaldehyde solution is also introduced as nitrogen resource by wetness impregnation method to further enhance the nitrogen content on the surface of biomass carbon materials as illustrated in Scheme 1 , which is attributed to the relatively enhanced thermal stability of polymers generated by formaldehyde and dicyandiamide. As a result, the grainy metal-free catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination is fabricated through the precursor carbonization in the one-step synthetic reaction. The BET results suggest that the grainy shape of N-doped biochar provides the larger specific surface area compared with powder-shaped carbon materials. Especially, the XPS result provides a powerful evidence that the superior catalytic activity of as-prepared metal-free catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination, such as the C2H2 conversion of 94.5% at 220°C and 45 h−1, is mainly caused by the high content of quaternary nitrogen in the nitrogen-doped biomass carbon materials. This work paves a new pathway for the utilization of walnut shells and also promotes the sustainable development of PVC industry through the application of high active metal-free catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination derived from environmentally friendly biomass carbon materials. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Walnut shells with a particle size of 1∼2 mm are used in this work. Dicyandiamide, formaldehyde and triethanolamine (TEA) are purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd and used as received. C2H2 (99.5%) and HCl (99.998%) are purchased from Jingong Special Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst fabrication Walnut shells are firstly carbonized at different temperatures for 4 h in a tubular furnace under argon atmosphere, denoted by BC-T where T is the carbonization temperature. Then, the N-doped biochar is prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method to further enhance the surficial nitrogen content as described in Scheme 1. Firstly, the dicyandiamide and formaldehyde (molar ratio 1:2) solution is agitated at room temperature till the impregnating solution become transparent. Then, after the solution is adjusted to pH=9∼10, walnut shells are fed, followed by agitating for 1 h, being aged for 16 h at room temperature and being dried at 125 °C. Finally, the N-doped biochar catalyst is gained by calcining the precursor at 850°C for 4 h in a tubular furnace under argon atmosphere, denoted as xDF/BC-850, where x is the mass ratio of dicyandiamide to walnut shell. Besides, another N-doped biochar is prepared using aqueous dicyandiamide solution as nitrogen source, denoted as xD/BC. Their difference is that the dissolving and impregnation temperature of dicyandiamide is carried out at 60 °C instead of room temperature. 2.3 Characterization Elemental analysis (EA) was conducted using a Vario EL/micro cube analysis instrument. Surface morphology was observed by a FEI Quanta 250 FEG scanning electronic microscopy (SEM). Raman spectra were tested using 532nm laser on Thermofisher DXRxi Raman imaging microscope. The functional groups on the surface of carbon materials were identified by AVATAR 370 via FTIR, in which the sample and KBr were mixed into a disc and pressed into a sheet. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on NETZSCH TGA instrument under nitrogen atmosphere at a flow rate of 50 mL∙ min−1 while the temperature increased from 30 to 600°C with a heating rate of 10°C∙min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) was recorded with a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi with monochromatic Al Kα X-ray as an excitation source to determine the surface chemical elements of the samples. The C1s signal at 284.8 eV was adopted to calibrate the binding energies. The N2 adsorption/desorption experiments of the catalysts were performed by Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ2 instrument. The BET measurements and DFT calculations were performed to obtain the specific surface areas and pore size distribution. 2.4 Catalytic experiment The catalytic performance of N-doped biochar for acetylene hydrochlorination was investigated in a fixed bed microreactor with a 10-mm-diameter quartz tube as illustrated in Fig. S1. About 10 mL of catalyst was placed in the reactor, followed by purging nitrogen gas to remove air and water at 120°C. HCl gas was then passed through the reactor at a flow rate of 0.5L·h−1 for 0.5 h to activate the catalyst. Finally, the reactor is heated to reaction temperature, and the mixed gases of HCl and C2H2(v(HCl)/v(C2H2) = 1.1∼1.2) were fed through the reactor with a gaseous hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 45 h−1. The gas products were passed through an adsorption bottle filled with NaOH aqueous solution and analyzed by SRI 310C gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of BC-T Walnut shells, as the lignified endocarp of walnuts, are an abundant waste material from the walnut processing procedure. Although their bulk density is low due to porous and wrinkled surface morphology as shown in Fig. S2a-c, they bear a hard texture structure for excellent mechanical characteristics, for example, the walnut shell particle of 1.25-1.60 mm in size is able to resist a compression power of 0.2295 KN. This compression-resistant feature provides a possibility for an outstanding mechanical intensity of walnut shell-based biochar. The porous and wrinkled morphology of walnut shells also indicates a large specific surface area in their biochar, which could be used as highly effective adsorbent to remove heavy metal ions from wastewater [49]. This feature is also a necessary precondition to achieve an excellent supporting material for highly efficient catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination. On the other hand, the chemical components of walnut shells mainly include lignin, cellulose and some organic aromatic compounds, which are the essential precursors being carbonized at different temperatures for the biochar (BC-T). During the carbonization of walnut shells, cellulose is aromatized by pyrolysis to form the carbon network planes, which are then stacked forming the carbon crystallites, i.e., the crystalline zone in the biochar. Lignin is difficult to undergo an effective structural rearrangement in the pyrolysis process. So, it is mainly melted and softened to form the amorphous carbon as the biochar skeleton [50]. The biochar surface presents an irregular perforated porous structure, whose pores are connected by membrane-like dense carbon as shown in Fig. S2d-e. In this way, the large specific surface area of as-fabricated biochar is propitious to the reactant adsorption and the increase of active sites. Finally, pristine or pyrolytic organic nitrogen-containing components in walnut shells, such as amino acids and piperidine/diazepine derivatives, are thermally polymerized to form the nitrogen-doped two-dimensional carbon materials on the biochar surface, presenting many quaternary nitrogen atoms as active sites for the catalytic reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination. The surficial deposition of pyrolytic nitrogen elements is proved by the higher surficial nitrogen content in Table S1 than the bulk nitrogen content in Table S2. As shown in the data in Table S2, the surficial nitrogen content of biochar is nearly increased about 13 times compared with pristine walnut shells. Simultaneously, the quaternary nitrogen ratio in the total nitrogen atoms is largely increased to 41.85at%.The pyrolysis of organic components in the carbonization process of walnut shells not only changes the proportion of nitrogen species in the biochar, which plays a key role in the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction, but also changes the elemental content of the biochar due to the gas emission, such as water, carbon dioxide and small molecule hydrocarbons, as illustrated in Tables S1-2. All these results are very propitious to the improvement of catalytic efficiency for acetylene hydrochlorination. The elemental mapping derived from EDS is provided in Fig. S3-4 to exhibit the uniform distribution of oxygen, carbon and nitrogen in walnut shells and BC-850. The structure and catalytic performance of biochar BC-T being carbonized at different temperatures are firstly investigated in detail. The Raman spectra of biochar BC-T are shown in Fig. 1 a. The D band at 1335 cm−1 exhibits the degree of disordered defects in the carbon materials while the G band at 1583 cm−1 reveals the graphitization degree of sp2 carbon atoms in the carbon framework. The intensity ratio of these two peaks (ID/IG) is considered to be a parameter of disorder degree associated with the carbon structure. Evidently, the more constructed defects at the high temperature favors the increase of catalytic activity for acetylene hydrochlorination [43,51], which will be proved by the following investigation of catalytic performance. Similarly, their FTIR spectra in Fig. 1b suggest the obvious weakened intensity of C=O peak at 1705 cm−1 after carbonization, including the new peak appearance at 1584 cm−1 being attributed to C=N [52, 53]. This result implies that the biochar BC-T derived from walnut shells forms a carbon and nitrogen framework, i.e., nitrogen-doped biochar. Notably, the catalytic performance at 180°C of BC-T for acetylene hydrochlorination in Fig. 2 a presents the evident relationship of acetylene conversion with nitrogen contents. The highest surficial nitrogen content of 4.13at% in BC-850 calcinated at the temperature of 850 °C as shown in Table S1 induces the highest acetylene conversion of ∼48% while its VCM selectivity is up to 99.85%, showing the best catalytic activity. Hence, the catalytic performance of biochar BC-T for acetylene hydrochlorination could be theoretically promoted by further enhancing the nitrogen content and active N site through the surface modification with definite nitrogen sources to impregnate walnut shells. 3.2 Catalytic performance of xD/BC-850 and xDF/BC-850 Based on the above conclusion, dicyandiamide with high nitrogen content is used as nitrogen source to dope the biomass activated carbon BC-T [54–56]. Due to the inadequate solubility in water of dicyandiamide at room temperature, the stoichiometric formaldehyde solution diluted with deionized water is introduced as solvent to generate the hydrophilic dicyandiamide-formaldehyde condensation product (molar ratio 1:2) with TEA to adjust to pH=9∼10. Thereby, the much larger content of dicyandiamide in the transparent impregnation solution is even acquired at room temperature. Except to promote the dispersion of dicyandiamide in the aqueous solution, the oxygen species in formaldehyde can also adjust the distribution of nitrogen species in the N-doped biochar [57,58]. Herein, the biochar BC-850 with the best catalytic performance is selected as the substrate to prepare the N-doped biochar, denoted as xDF/BC-850. Different mass ratio (x) of dicyandiamide and walnut shell is adopted to adjust the nitrogen content on the surface of biochar BC-850 with an aim to further regulate the catalytic activity of N-doped biochar xDF/BC-850. The thermal gravimetric analysis is firstly used to investigate the residual weight of dicyandiamide and dicyandiamide-formaldehyde resin powder after the calcination at high temperature. From the curves in Fig. 3 a, the rapid decomposition of dicyandiamide occurs between 232 °C and 385 °C, while the polycondensation for dicyandiamide-formaldehyde resin occurs below 274 °C with the emission of water, followed by a quick decomposition in higher temperature. At 600 °C, the residual weight percentages of dicyandiamide and dicyandiamide-formaldehyde resin powder are about 21.7wt% and 47.5wt%, respectively. Undoubtedly, the better thermal stability of dicyandiamide-formaldehyde resin than dicyandiamide provides a precondition to more efficiently fix the nitrogen atoms on the surface of as-fabricated N-doped biochar. The FTIR spectra of BC-850, 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 in Fig. 3b illustrates that the peak at 3428 cm−1, associated with the amino (-NH2) and imino (-NH-) stretching vibration, overlaps with the stretching vibration corresponding to hydroxyl group (-OH) [59]. In addition, the peaks at 1737 cm−1 and 1567 cm−1 are attributed to C=O and C=N, respectively. And, the peak intensities at these positions for both 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 are higher than pristine BC-850, indicating the possibility of successful nitrogen-doping towards the biochar. Besides, the SEM images of BC-850, 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 in Fig. 4 indicates that, compared to the pristine biomass carbon Fig. 4a, many microspheres are formed on the biochar surface after loading the nitrogen species as shown in Fig. 4b,c.The SEM image of 6D/BC-850 in Fig. 4b suggests the serious microsphere aggregation on the biochar surface due to the formaldehyde absence. With the addition of formaldehyde, the microsphere aggregation is evidently alleviated as shown in Fig. 4c. This point is in accord with the above material design, that the introduction of formaldehyde could enhance the thermal stability of polymers generated by formaldehyde and dicyandiamide and then adjust the content and distribution of nitrogen species on the surface of N-doped biochar. This change of surficial morphology is very good for the improvement of catalytic activity due to the effective absorption and collision of reactive precursors in acetylene hydrochlorination, which is the extensively accepted reaction mechanism between hydrogen chloride and acetylene up to now. First of all, the catalytic performance at 220°C of formaldehyde-free xD/BC-850 with different dicyandiamide-loading amounts is evaluated with C2H2 GHSV of 45 h−1 at reaction temperature of 220°C as shown in Fig. 5 a,b. It can be obviously seen that dicyandiamide is an excellent choice of nitrogen sources. With the dicyandiamide-loading amount increasing from 1% to 6%, the acetylene conversion is gradually promoted to 94.92% in the 6D/BC-850 catalyst, which is considerably higher than ∼70% of BC-850. At the same time, the VCM selectivity is also increased to a certain extent and turns to be stable. However, excessive dicyandiamide-loading amount, more than 6%, causes acetylene conversion to drop quickly including the more instable and worse VCM selectivity. Herein, the deterioration of catalytic performance is probably caused by the deficient contact between active sites and reactant gases, which is caused by the pore blockage and the above serious microsphere aggregation at the high nitrogen-loading amount. To make clear the action of formaldehyde on the catalytic activity of acetylene hydrochlorination, the catalytic performance of xDF/BC-850 catalysts at the same reaction condition is also provided in Fig. 5c,d. Obviously, xDF/BC-850 displays much higher catalytic activity than BC-850, too. When the loading dosage of dicyandiamide-formaldehyde is 2.5%, the obtained 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst shows the best catalytic activity, such as the acetylene conversion of 94.45% and the VCM selectivity of 99.9%. Through the comparation of catalytic performance for xD/BC-850 and xDF/BC-850, the similar catalytic activity is achieved except for the dosage of dicyandiamide nitrogen source in the present of formaldehyde. Evidently, the formaldehyde solution is not only an effective solvent for dicyandiamide, but also effectively participates in the polycarbonization reaction in the preparation of N-doped biochar catalysts. This result further proves that the formaldehyde could adjust the distribution of nitrogen species on the surface of N-doped biochar. The 20-hour catalytic reactions with 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 catalysts under the reaction conditions of C2H2 GHSV 45h−1 and 220°C, as shown in Fig. S5, suggest that the acetylene conversion of 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst is more stable than 6D/BC-850 catalyst with the conversion decline of 2.5DF/BC-850 from 94.45% to 90.54%, but that of 6D/BC-850 from 94.92% to 87.43%. The deactivation reason of catalytic activity is mainly attributed to the carbon deposition producing the loss of active sites. The calculated deactivation rate of 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst is about 0.19% h−1, which is compared to the previous studies [40,43,51]. Out of question, the introduction of formaldehyde is quite beneficial to the catalytic stability of N-doped biochar catalyst. 3.3 Catalyst characterization The XPS measurements are performed to evaluate the N-doping content on the surface of N-doped biochar catalysts, including the nitrogen elemental types, which are some important active sites for acetylene hydrochlorination [44]. Fig. 6 a shows the binding energies of C1s (284.8 eV), N1s (400.8 eV) and O1s (532.8 eV), in which the high-resolved N1s spectra of BC-850, 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 are respectively fitted in Fig. 6b-d. The fitting results exhibit three main peaks, such as pyridinic nitrogen (399.3 ± 0.3 eV), pyrrolic nitrogen (400.9 ± 0.3 eV) and quaternary nitrogen (401.9 ± 0.3 eV), respectively [60,61]. Differently from BC-850 in the Table 1 , the 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 catalysts bear the similar proportion of nitrogen species on the surface although the nitrogen content is decreased to a certain extent, proving the successful modification of walnut shell-based biochar by dicyandiamide. One of them, the quaternary nitrogen is the main nitrogen species with a high proportion of ∼60%, which is considered to be the main active center for acetylene hydrochlorination. Of course, other nitrogen species, such as pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen, can also exhibit a certain catalytic activity as reported in the literature [42,62]. In this case, the calcination temperature is speculated to another important factor to determine the formation of different nitrogen species in the N-doped biochar except for the application of formaldehyde in the biochar fabrication. The oxygen element derived from the introduction of formaldehyde might impact the catalytic activity by tuning the distribution of different nitrogen species on the N-doped biochar surface. The N2 adsorption/desorption experiment is performed by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) measurement to understand the effect of formaldehyde on the pore structure in the biochar catalysts. The nitrogen adsorption isothermal curves in Fig. S6 illustrate that the pristine/used 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 catalysts follow the I-type isotherms according to the IUPAC classification. The unclosed hysteresis loop indicates that the microporous structure of biochar catalysts contributes to the major specific surface area. As shown in the BET data of Table 2 , pristine 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst basically shows a unchangeable specific surface area (541.64 m2·g−1) after the introduction of formaldehyde compared to BC-850 (550.43 m2·g−1) while pristine 6D/BC-850 catalyst (461.19 m2·g−1) takes on a decrease of 16.2% (approximately 90 m2∙g−1). After the 20-hour reaction, the specific surface area of 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst decreases about 28.3% from 541.64 m2∙g−1 to 388.39 m2∙g−1, while the specific surface area of 6D/BC-850 catalyst more largely decreases about 56.6% from 461.19 m2∙g−1 to 199.98 m2∙g−1. The macroporous data in Table S3, which are tested by mercury porosimeter as shown in Figs. S7-11, reveal the same trend as the BET data in Table 2. These results confirm that the formation of carbon deposition causes the pore-plugging in the biochar catalyst, resulting in the decline of catalytic activity [63]. However, this situation could be remarkably improved by the application of formaldehyde in the process of dicyandiamide dissolution. The change of specific surface area in the pristine/used 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 catalysts is investigated by observing the residual natural pores via the scanning electron microscopy as shown in Fig. 7 . It is seen from Fig. 7a,b that many agglomerated particles are distributed on the surface of pristine 6D/BC-850 catalyst and the serious carbon deposition blocks the pores on the biochar surface after the catalytic reaction, which not only cover the active sites but also hinder the transfer and diffusion of reactant gases. As a result, the acetylene conversion of 6D/BC-850 will be decreased till the catalyst deactivation. On the contrary, there is no serious carbon deposition to be found on the used 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst after the catalytic reaction as displayed in Fig. 7c,d. This result verifies that the introduction of formaldehyde effectively solidifies the biochar surface and then inhibits the generation of carbon deposition, which is consistent with the BET analytic result. The level of carbon deposition on the catalyst surface is evaluated by thermogravimetric analysis, which is calculated according to the weight-losing ratio over an appropriate temperature range as reported in the literature [51,64]. As illustrated in Fig. 8 , the catalyst weight-losing before 150°C is attributed to the water evaporation in the catalyst surface and the weight-losing between 150°C to 400°C is mainly caused by the combustion of carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. Table 3 provides the weight-losing ratio up to 400°C of pristine/used 6D/BC-850 and 2.5DF/BC-850 catalysts, together with the amount of carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. Evidently, the carbon deposition for 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst is 0.76%, which is much lower than 3.58% of 6D/BC-850 catalyst. This result directly indicates that the addition of formaldehyde effectively inhibits the formation of carbon deposition and then greatly improves the stability of N-doped biochar catalyst, which is completely consistent with the results of catalytic performance. Undoubtedly, this work provides an environmentally friendly metal-free N-doped biochar catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination, whose high-efficient and stable features pave the way for the green mass-production of acetylene hydrochlorination. 4 Conclusions The walnut shell-based N-doped biochar catalysts are prepared via a wetness impregnation method, followed by being carbonized in the inert atmosphere at a certain calcination temperature. Compared with the single dicyandiamide nitrogen source, the introduction of formaldehyde into the hydrous dicyandiamide solution not only promotes the dicyandiamide dispersion in the water solution, but also effectively alleviates the generation of carbon deposition on the biochar surface. The XPS result indicates that the quaternary nitrogen species is the main active sites in the N-doped biochar catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. This work provides an environmentally friendly metal-free N-doped biochar catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination. Especially, the high-efficient and stable characteristics of as-fabricated N-doped biochar catalyst have the intriguing potential for the green mass-production of acetylene hydrochlorination. coredata.dc:description: Mercuric chloride as main catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination poses a serious hazard to the environment due to its easily volatilizing and highly toxic characteristics. Mercuric-free catalysts, especially metal-free catalysts, are quite intriguing in the industrial production of acetylene hydrochlorination. In this work, nitrogen-doped biochar is prepared as green metal-free catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination with natural walnut shells as starting material, in which the condensation product of dicyandiamide or dicyandiamide-formaldehyde is applied as nitrogen source. The 2.5DF/BC-850 catalyst exhibits superior catalytic activity with C2H2 conversion of 94.5% at 220°C and 45 h−1, which is attributed to the high content of quaternary nitrogen as active center. The introduction of formaldehyde effectively inhibits the carbon deposition in the catalytic reaction and improves the thermal stability of metal-free nitrogen-doped biochar catalyst. This work provides a significant insight into the design of environmentally friendly metal-free nitrogen-doped biochar catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination.
coredata.dc:title: Environmentally friendly high-efficient metal-free catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination derived from walnut shell-based N-doped biochar
